Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of the I-Corps project is the development of a prototype geodetic satellite-based gravity observational system and the associated cloud-based computing tools for the rapid remote monitoring of floods, droughts, and freshwater resources availability globally at basin scales. The project is expected to enable efficient, dynamic, big data quantifications of freshwater transport for a wide range of potential commercial applications. The potential commercialization of this tool and the timely availability of the associate data products could provide critical information and impact on commercial applications including precision agriculture, disaster planning and management, as well as general water resources management.

This I-Corps project will explore the commercialization of a cloud-based satellite temporal gravity observation processing and visualization tool. This is designed for rapid monitoring with up to daily temporal sampling for natural or anthropogenic features. The project builds from prior developments improving the temporal resolution of water storage change and potentially improving its spatial resolution. Current commercially available tools for agricultural and disaster/water resources management services are primarily based on passive remote sensing imaging which are typically limited by cloud cover or are prohibitively expensive for acquiring timely data sets. As Earth satellite gravity mission data sets continue into the next decade, the data underpinning this work is freely available and potentially updated in near real time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Briefly description of our product

We have developed an initial prototype system to demonstrate the feasibility of daily-sampled, shorter data averaging span (than 1 month and at 11 days) to invert for large-scale terrestrial water storage measurements from the GRACE (Gravity Recovery And Climate Experiment) or the future GRACE-Followon (GRACE-FO) twin-satellite gravity mission, for potential commercial applications including flood, drought, and groundwater resources monitoring.  The goal is to achieve the rigorous inversion with a low latency for the products, that is, the total terrestrial water storage and groundwater storage changes, for efficient disasters and water resources management.  satellite time-variable gravity inversion, which has extended the current sampling interval of from a month to daily, reducing the solution data (mass change) span from 1 month to 10 days. A user-friendly visualization tool is planned to accomplish the inversion tool.  A plan to undertake additional technological enhancement and to overcome technical limitation became more mature during the project.

The potential commercial customers

We intend to approach customers or to discover customers from agricultural and water resources management related industries. Current customers in water resources management agencies, agricultural companies, have not yet used such a geodetic remote sensing tool, which is high level over a large basin or with sub-weekly temporal sampling. But in reality, the needs of customers and value propositions of our product are not what we thought. Through the NSF I-Corp training, we approach, interview and explore the potential commercial customers and figure out the exact value proposition and customer segment.

Major Activities, Objectives, Significant Results & Key Outcomes/Other Achievements

During the two months (07~08/2017), we total interviewed 122 potential customers, in which 76 in person, 5 through video chat, and 41 through phone calls. The interviewers include farmers, director and members of National Ground Water Association (NGWA), satellite image companies, national and international precision farming and agricultural companies, United States Geological Survey (USGS), and state local water districts, in Nebraska, Kansas, Texas, Arizona and California. We attended 2017 Four State Farm Show, the 2017 Groundwater Solutions Conference to reach more interviewers and customers.  We also ventured into India and interviewed up to 10 international/national companies with interdisciplinary business models. 


Last Modified: 11/01/2018
Modified by: C. K. Shum
